htmlEmbed:
Privacy FAQ - The New York Times3/5/2022

At The Times, we aim to create the best possible reader experience across every medium. This involves knowing certain things about our readership. For example, knowing which articles you read helps us understand your interests. That information lets us select the types of articles we show you in certain parts of the app or site. (This article selection process is still guided by our journalistic judgment, and doesn’t impact large portions of the app or site.)

data-testid="PrivacyFaq"><div class="HeroSection"><section class="css-10g1wgm"><div class="css-ykay9g"><div class="css-151006m"><p class="css-15lp4zh">The Times and Your Data</p><h1 class="css-t6j03b">Privacy F.A.Q.</h1></div></div></section><header class="css-2a5sns" role="presentation"><div class="css-ykay9g"><div class="css-151006m"><p class="css-19sckwj">The Times and Your Data</p><h1 class="css-lpwl7b">The trust of our readers is essential.</h1></div></div></header></div><section class="css-lwsze8"><div class="css-120l22k" id="main-content"><p class="css-1a1sxkz">Our readers should know how we handle their data.</p><p class="css-1a1sxkz">We created this page to answer our readers’ questions about how we use their personal data. This topic is important to many readers, and we value their right to understand how it works.</p><p class="css-1a1sxkz">This F.A.Q. applies to nytimes.com readers. If you want to dive deeper into the details, please see our <a class="css-1j7tmuv" href="/privacy/privacy-policy">Privacy Policy</a>.</p></div></section><div class="FaqComponent" id="faqComponent"><section class="css-1p8efyv" id="faq-section"><div class="css-ykay9g"><div class="css-jes3yq"><h2 class="css-ehcpqz">Frequently asked questions</h2><button type="button" class="css-zl1zn3" aria-label="collapse and expand all accordions"><svg width="18" height="26" viewBox="0 0 18 26" fill="none"><path d="M2 16L9 23L16 16" stroke="#23855B" stroke-width="4"></path><path d="M16 10L9 3L2 10" stroke="#23855B" stroke-width="4"></path></svg></button></div><div class="css-19xyuqs"><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="why-does-the-times-collect-and-use-my-data"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-why-does-the-times-collect-and-use-my-data" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">1<!-- -->.</div><span>Why does The Times collect (and use) my data?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-why-does-the-times-collect-and-use-my-data" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="why-does-the-times-collect-and-use-my-data" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">At The Times, we aim to create the best possible reader experience across every medium. This involves knowing certain things about our readership. For example, knowing which articles you read helps us understand your interests. That information lets us select the types of articles we show you in certain parts of the app or site. (This article selection process is still guided by our journalistic judgment, and doesn’t impact large portions of the app or site.)</p><p class="css-o6cyx">It is important to note that The Times is primarily funded by subscriptions and advertising. Both functions require the use of readers’ data. For example, we use readers’ data to identify who may be interested in a subscription in order to show you Times ads on other websites. Our advertisers ask us to use reader data so their ads can be targeted at the right audiences.</p></div></section><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="what-type-of-data-is-collected-about-me"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-what-type-of-data-is-collected-about-me" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">2<!-- -->.</div><span>What type of data is collected about me when I’m accessing The Times?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-what-type-of-data-is-collected-about-me" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="what-type-of-data-is-collected-about-me" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">Different types of data are collected based on the different Times services you use. There are effectively two types of data collection: direct and indirect.</p><p class="css-o6cyx">Direct data collection means you are submitting data to us. For example, when you create an account with The Times, you submit your email address to set up and personalize it.</p><p class="css-o6cyx">Indirect data collection takes place passively as you interact with our site or apps. Our tracking technologies collect data about your reading behavior, like which articles you read or how often you visit The Times. Third-party advertisers collect behavioral data associated with their ads shown on our site or apps. Additionally, we collect data about readers from sources like privately owned databases and social media platforms.</p></div></section><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="what-does-the-times-do-with-the-data-it-collects-on-me"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-what-does-the-times-do-with-the-data-it-collects-on-me" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">3<!-- -->.</div><span>What does The Times do with data it collects on me?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-what-does-the-times-do-with-the-data-it-collects-on-me" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="what-does-the-times-do-with-the-data-it-collects-on-me" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">We use it to cater our journalism and other offerings to you, like by recommending stories that may be of interest. The specific data we use depends on the offering, and how you are accessing it. We also use your data to tailor your experience, which includes marketing and advertising.</p></div></section><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="how-are-you-keeping-my-data-safe"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-how-are-you-keeping-my-data-safe" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">4<!-- -->.</div><span>How are you keeping my data safe?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-how-are-you-keeping-my-data-safe" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="how-are-you-keeping-my-data-safe" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">We have implemented organizational, technological and physical safeguards designed to keep our readers’ data secure internally. The Times is dedicated to building, maintaining and upgrading the measures we take to protect your data.</p></div></section><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="what-are-some-ways-i-can-protect-my-data"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-what-are-some-ways-i-can-protect-my-data" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">5<!-- -->.</div><span>What are some ways I can protect my data?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-what-are-some-ways-i-can-protect-my-data" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="what-are-some-ways-i-can-protect-my-data" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">We encourage our readers to take steps to safeguard their own data. We recently published a guide on this topic: <a class="css-1dvjakn" href="https://www.nytimes.com/guides/privacy-project/how-to-protect-your-digital-privacy">How to Protect Your Digital Privacy</a>.</p></div></section><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="why-am-i-given-the-option-to-use-facebook-and-google"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-why-am-i-given-the-option-to-use-facebook-and-google" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">6<!-- -->.</div><span>Why am I given the option to use Facebook and Google for log-in?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-why-am-i-given-the-option-to-use-facebook-and-google" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="why-am-i-given-the-option-to-use-facebook-and-google" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">Our readers have voiced a desire for our log-in process to be even simpler.</p><p class="css-o6cyx">If you sign up via Facebook or Google, they share limited data with us so we can create an account for you. We do not share any data about your reading behavior with Facebook or Google when you sign up. To learn more, see our <a class="css-1dvjakn" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014887628-Social-login">social login page</a>.</p></div></section><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="how-can-i-learn-more-about-how-companies-use-personal-data-online"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-how-can-i-learn-more-about-how-companies-use-personal-data-online" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">7<!-- -->.</div><span>How can I learn more about how companies use personal data online?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-how-can-i-learn-more-about-how-companies-use-personal-data-online" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="how-can-i-learn-more-about-how-companies-use-personal-data-online" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">The Times regularly publishes pieces on the topic, including in <a class="css-1dvjakn" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/04/business/secret-consumer-score-access.html">Business</a>, <a class="css-1dvjakn" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/19/technology/artificial-intelligence-dawn-song.html">Technology</a>, and <a class="css-1dvjakn" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/24/smarter-living/privacy-online-how-to-stop-advertiser-tracking-opt-out.html">Smarter Living</a>.</p><p class="css-o6cyx">Our Opinion series, <a class="css-1dvjakn" href="https://www.nytimes.com/series/new-york-times-privacy-project">The Privacy Project</a>, explains how online privacy affects your daily life — and shows you how to take control of your data.</p></div></section><section class="css-1hwfw1e" id="does-the-times-support-the-gpc"><h3><button type="button" class="css-1vu44uy" aria-expanded="true" aria-controls="region-does-the-times-support-the-gpc" aria-disabled="false"><div class="css-7lgvd5">8<!-- -->.</div><span>Does The Times support the Global Privacy Control (GPC)?</span><div class="css-7rj3o4"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="12" fill="#949494"></circle><path d="M6 11H18V13H6V11Z" fill="white"></path></svg></div></button></h3><div id="region-does-the-times-support-the-gpc" class="accordion-content answer open" role="region" aria-labelledby="does-the-times-support-the-gpc" aria-hidden="false"><p class="css-o6cyx">Yes.</p><p class="css-o6cyx">When we detect a GPC signal from a reader’s browser where GDPR, CCPA or a similar privacy law applies, we stop sharing the reader’s personal data online with other companies (except with our service providers).</p><p class="css-o6cyx">You can learn more about the GPC — and how to enable it in your browser — from the <a class="css-1dvjakn" href="https://globalprivacycontrol.org/">Global Privacy Control</a> <!-- -->website.</p></div></section></div></div></section></div><section class="css-pq0jc2"><div readabilityObject.title: Privacy FAQ - The New York Times
readabilityObject.content:
At The Times, we aim to create the best possible reader experience across every medium. This involves knowing certain things about our readership. For example, knowing which articles you read helps us understand your interests. That information lets us select the types of articles we show you in certain parts of the app or site. (This article selection process is still guided by our journalistic judgment, and doesn’t impact large portions of the app or site.)

It is important to note that The Times is primarily funded by subscriptions and advertising. Both functions require the use of readers’ data. For example, we use readers’ data to identify who may be interested in a subscription in order to show you Times ads on other websites. Our advertisers ask us to use reader data so their ads can be targeted at the right audiences.

Different types of data are collected based on the different Times services you use. There are effectively two types of data collection: direct and indirect.

Direct data collection means you are submitting data to us. For example, when you create an account with The Times, you submit your email address to set up and personalize it.

Indirect data collection takes place passively as you interact with our site or apps. Our tracking technologies collect data about your reading behavior, like which articles you read or how often you visit The Times. Third-party advertisers collect behavioral data associated with their ads shown on our site or apps. Additionally, we collect data about readers from sources like privately owned databases and social media platforms.

We use it to cater our journalism and other offerings to you, like by recommending stories that may be of interest. The specific data we use depends on the offering, and how you are accessing it. We also use your data to tailor your experience, which includes marketing and advertising.

We have implemented organizational, technological and physical safeguards designed to keep our readers’ data secure internally. The Times is dedicated to building, maintaining and upgrading the measures we take to protect your data.

We encourage our readers to take steps to safeguard their own data. We recently published a guide on this topic: How to Protect Your Digital Privacy.

Our readers have voiced a desire for our log-in process to be even simpler.

If you sign up via Facebook or Google, they share limited data with us so we can create an account for you. We do not share any data about your reading behavior with Facebook or Google when you sign up. To learn more, see our social login page.

The Times regularly publishes pieces on the topic, including in Business, Technology, and Smarter Living.

Our Opinion series, The Privacy Project, explains how online privacy affects your daily life — and shows you how to take control of your data.

Yes.

When we detect a GPC signal from a reader’s browser where GDPR, CCPA or a similar privacy law applies, we stop sharing the reader’s personal data online with other companies (except with our service providers).

You can learn more about the GPC — and how to enable it in your browser — from the Global Privacy Control website.
